comments.commentBody: Nuschler - you do know - or maybe not- that Fred Thompson was tipping off the Nixon White House and their witnesses as to the day's questions and throwing softballs until Butterfield 'misspoke' about the taping system and the whole shebang blew up?
I had greater respect for him than Clinton.  Or either of them for that matter.

He did a superb job in the Watergate hearings. He wasn’t there to polish his image but to ask clear questions in short sentences designed to exact precise answers. Both he and then Senator Joe Biden were exemplary in their jobs.

Comparing them to the clowns that ran the Benghazi hearings was night and day.

I liked him both as the hard nosed hard right wing Arthur Branch on Law and Order (I enjoyed his head to head battles with the more leftist Sam Waterston as ADA Jack McCoy) and as the real prosecutor in the Watergate hearings. I will miss him...but then L&O will always find a syndication spot on TV!

I felt badly for him in the 2007-2008 GOP nominations. He couldn’t quite separate out the actor from the politician. But I had greater respect for him than I did for Reagan.

Sadly, increasingly, Fred Thomson does epitomize the role of U.S. Senator, but, not as you attempt to insert, against all facts, by 'not seeking higher office.'  Fred did seek the Presidency you might recall.  Facts are so unfair.  Stubborn things, as John Adams observed.
"Who knows what that was about?" Is that the way you gloss over his selling his likeness to convince gullible seniors to sign over the equity in their homes?
What a bunch of twaddle Pedro.  Gore may be boring, but, the money he made other than what he inherited was from investing in Google.  Their is a trollish cast to your multiple lies and posts.
They are 'snarking' about his shilling for fraudulently represented usurious loans, Pedro - not his politics.  Dear God, learn to read!
Interesting. Wish I could get the book here!

First ''Pedro'' admonishes ''Libs'' for taking poor Freddy to task for contributing to a product that defrauds oldsters of their last remaining asset for 'bashing the deceased'' - then he exhumes the corpse of Ted Kennedy to spit on it.  Now that's a proud republican troll for ya!

Dear me, Pedro, does one have to be a Liberal Hillary voter to object to the unsavory spectacle of Mr. Yhompson using his prestige to try to foist a potentially product on the unwary?  We've got lots of friends of all stripes, and they all had issues with these commercials.  Perhaps snake oil is popular n Idaho, but we don't cotton to it in New York, no matter what our political leanings.
Your "This is a glimpse into the psyche of HIllary voters" is trite. And to that I can justifiably say, "Whatever."

comments.userDisplayName: Get the Fox out of the Henhouse
comments.commentBody: Which of his families, Mark?  I'm sure my family on my brother's side would like to get their in-laws reverse mortgage released.  How about some sympathy  for the victims from you Republicans, instead of false veneration and piety for the recently departed con men?
I vote for down the drain - the latter choice.

Whatever, did you bother to read my comment properly? It wasn't my situation that was or is the issue - it was the situation of two quite separate elderly people. It is evident that you know nothing at all about reverse mortgages, having neither researched them in any depth or having even considered taking one out yourself.

The so-called 'facts' on the HUD Frequently Asked Questions about HUD's Reverse Mortgages to which you link are not facts at all. They are specious generalisations no different from the generalised hand waving one about reverse mortgages can read on any marketing page anywhere.

Where are the figures on this FAQ page showing how many homes have to be sold? Answer: there aren't any because it's just a government-sponsored spruik. Why then are you commenting about something about which by your own admission you have no knowledge?

You want some facts? I suggest you start with http://www.forbes.com/sites/carolynrosenblatt/2012/07/23/hidden-truths-a...

right, Pedro - stop with the partisan blathering - so, we should forget about all of those hateful and nasty comments made about Obama and Hillary... tell me again who is "at heart, nasty, bitter, unforgiving, truculent, empty" ??

Pedro - I can't recall seeing Hillary Clinton in a commercial urging my mom to call now and cash in on her paid for home by burdening it with a first lien that has precipitous penalties for liquidation and is essentially predatory and irreversible.  But, I've heard Fred's mellifluous baritone urging seniors to do just that countless times.  He did more than 'a few commercials.'  You lie.  Just like Ben Carson lied when he failed to acknowledge he'd been doing infomercials and was under contract with his 'nutritional supplement' employer.
Nice combination of flavors. Used 4 lb of bone-in shoulder chops. Made a more elegant presentation but might increase to 5 lb next time. Also reduce stock to 2 cups.  Too much liquid.
however under-spiced this recipe appears to be, this *is* the recipe in edna lewis's "the taste of country cooking."

In this column, pieceofcake is the only one seeing the forest and the trees. Everyone else has undies in a bunch over nothing. Who cares what the econ concepts of full employment and stable inflation are? We are outside the bounds of all of them now that the world is one giant labor market losing out to automation.

And the only problem with this academic exercise to find the 'natural rate of interest' is our itonius reality.
If an economy puts as much impetus on financial engineering and speculation as the US - permanently low interest rates motivate speculators and gamblers in hordes - and the damage they are causing always have to be offset against the positive effects of the low rates.
There is no doubt that... lets call them 'low' rates set by the FED - help the unemployed and the economy - and the FED says so - but how much of this help is offset by the damage done by speculation and thus higher costs for basic needs like housing? And if the speculators and gamblers again will overdo it by using the low rates so extensively that we get another correction of the stock boom by 10 to 13 percent like in August - we have to consider it a medicine which might kill the patient.
And then we could talk about how to built a sustainable economy based on 'natural' -(and not financial) conditions?

To ceilidth: I absolutely do not condone the behavior of the teacher, but teachers aren't perfect either. This country is devoid of any human compassion.

The officer made a grave, violent mistake. The teacher and the student both made errors, but nothing deserving of expulsion or getting fired.

Is everyone so perfect? Is everyone so free of error in their teen years? For four whole years, through all pressure, never, ever to make a mistake?

What ever happened to forgiveness? I'm not even a Christian but I still believe in compassion and mercy and repentance and becoming a better person.
I have baked this cake twice. It is the perfect after dinner cake with a nice espresso. I play up the clove, coffee and and add cocoa nibs. Very adult flavor, complex and sophisticated, not to sweet.

I was able to manage the broiler, but it seemed that the flavors of the fennel, pepper, etc. did not transfer to the chicken so that came out fairly plain. Perhaps I would have rubbed the chicken with the pepper and garlic beforehand to give it some oomph?

Good, but a bit subtle. Next time I'll try a lot more pepper. The butter burns, so line the baking dish with foil for easier clean-up. A stick blender was helpful in getting a smooth blend of miso paste and butter.

Charges often double for procedures provided by the same doctor in the same facility, with the same staff as provided prior to the purchase of the practice by the hospital. Nothing the hospital does for the doctor's practice justifies such an increase. We need some competition in medicine. If hospitals can charge unnecessary "facility fee" independent physicians can not compete, and the cost of medical care escalates unnecessarily. It's time that congress stood up to the hospital lobby and banned facility fees, and not reimburse hospitals at a higher rate than independent physicians. Congress should then go after the pharmaceutical companies for abusing patent protection and overcharging, and also prevent hedge fund operators from buying companies that manufacture generic drugs and overcharging. Too much of the healthcare dollar is going to administrative overhead, investor profit, and insurance administrative costs. Many of the costs are often hidden and on paper are presented as direct costs for medical care, such as the cost of a doctor's time spent providing documentation for prior authorization, and other documentation unnecessary for direct medical care. We need to better identify what is the actual cost for medication, and for direct services without the demands of third party payor and auditors, Then if such documentation demands are placed on clinicians they should be identified as administrative overhead and appropriate limits placed on that expense.

Bernie Sanders said that Congress doesn't regulate Wall Street, Wall Street regulates congress. It's not confined Wall Street and the Congress, though. It's widespread corruption in our corporate & financial sectors that infects our legal and political systems. Where is the outrage of those politicians who wear the flag in their lapel and proclaim their reverence for freedom and the US constitution?

I remember learning years ago in history class how corrupt the British political system used to be; the Parliament was packed by patronage members from grossly over-represented "rotten boroughs" before a reform movement forced things to change. The striking, and depressing, difference between the UK then and the US now is that the US reform is going in the wrong direction. It is stealthily but surely working against, instead of serving, the interests of ordinary Americans. The US is becoming one giant rotten borough.
A definite keeper. Used baby swiss instead of fontina. Didn't find it too salty. Like the suggestion to add a slice of tomato.

Bad puzzle today.

62 total answers and fully half -- 31 -- being proper nouns with a couple of foreign phrases thrown in for good measure.

If I wanted to play a puzzle full of bold face names and places I would pick up TV Guide.
